post_text:
Lee County School District teachers and staff were honored during last night's school board meeting by Mike Mitchell with United Way of Northeast Mississippi.

Mr. Mitchell presented the "Achievement Award" to LCSD. The award recognizes the campaign with the largest dollar increase for campaigns over $10,000.
The district received this award for the second year in a row! Employees increased their already record-setting campaign from $66,847 to $74,848 -- an increase of over $8,000.

LCSD also received the "Community Impact Award" for employee giving over $50,000 and a "Bronze Award" for employee participation between 25-49%.

We salute our employees who generously and consistently give back to this community!

post_text:
The Lee County School District held a groundbreaking ceremony this morning for our new Career and Technical Education Center.

The complex will be located in The Hive Business Park on Highway 6 West. It will accommodate four shop-based classes and five classroom-based classes.

Proposed pathways include:
*Health Science
*Teacher Academy
*Information Technology
*Hospitality and Tourism
*Construction/Carpentry
*Transportation, Distribution and Logistics
*Industrial Maintenance
*Ag Power Equipment/Ag and Natural Resources

Lee County School District voters overwhelmingly approved a $15 million dollar bond issue in January of this year to finance the center. This bond requires no tax increase for LCSD taxpayers.

Plans are to have the building ready for classes starting in August 2021.

Children entering a Mississippi school (from pre-kindergarten to 12th grade) for the first time are required to have the following vaccinations:

Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis (DTaP)
Polio (IPV)
Hepatitis B
Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR)
Chickenpox (Varicella)

If your child is entering the seventh grade, either by advancing or transferring in, a pertussis (Tdap) booster is now required if they have not received a Tdap vaccination since the age of seven.

Vaccinations are available from the health department clinic in any county, or from your medical provider.

Please read more from the Mississippi State Department of Health: https://msdh.ms.gov/msdhsite/_static/14,8569,71.html

Mrs. Swords, Mrs. McNutt and Mrs. Waite's fourth grade classes at Saltillo Elementary completed a lesson to learn more about last week's Martin Luther King, Jr., Day.

Students first watched a biography video on Martin Luther King, Jr., and read a biography on Pablo Picasso. Classes had an open discussion about how different life was for the two men, as well as the similarities they shared.

Students viewed Pablo Picasso’s art piece “Bouquet of Peace,” discussed an article on its significance, and learned of Picasso’s role to create peace in the world.
Students then heard pieces of Martin Luther King, Jr.’s famous "I Have a Dream" speech. They discussed specific quotes from his speech that spoke to students personally about peace.

Classes later created their own “Bouquet of Flowers” collage, patterned after Picasso's work.
Once they completed their pieces, students selected a portion of King's speech to write on cards that were placed on their flowers.
#artsintegration #MLKDay

We appreciate the large turnout from students, parents and team sponsors!
